reasoning: Crucial because it bears directly on whether compute bottlenecks meaningfully constrain a software intelligence explosion: if “compute-light” routes can drive large capability gains, the paper’s anti-bottleneck/strongest-link stance is strengthened; if not, the CES-style complementarity objection gains force. Fairly paper-specific since it targets the paper’s strongest-link vs bottleneck framing and implicit substitutability claims, though it could be asked of other SIE/compute-bottleneck discussions. Partially tractable via empirical decomposition of frontier progress (algorithmic efficiency trends, ablation-style case studies of major advances, spend/compute accounting, proxy measures of ‘idea’ vs ‘experiment’ contributions), but causal attribution and counterfactual ‘sufficient alone’ claims are difficult. Clarity is decent but key terms are underspecified (what counts as compute-intensive/light; what operationalizes “multi-OOM capability gains”; what “alone” means). Decision hook is present but not fully action-explicit (it implies which model/frame to use, but not concretely what strategic priorities change). Low dead weight: the framing mostly supports the question without excessive padding.
title: Compute-intensive iteration versus alternative routes for capability scaling
